perturbation.original_text: 5.1. The term of this JSMA shall commence on May 1, 2020 (the “Commencement Date”) and ends at April 30, 2029 (the “Term”), with automatic renewals each for a period of five (5) years (a “Renewal Term”) unless notice is given pursuant to 5.2.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.1. The term of this JSMA shall commence on May 1, 2020 (the “Commencement Date”) and ends at April 30, 2029 (the “Term”). Renewal of this JSMA for any period after the initial term will require written agreement by both parties, made no less than 30 days before the original term expires.
perturbation.explanation: Section 5.1 originally stated the JSMA has automatic renewals unless notice is given, but the modified section removes 'automatic' renewal and stipulates a new agreement must be made, which directly contradicts the concept of automatic renewals.

perturbation.original_text: 6.1.1. A Party fails to make, when due, any payment under this JSMA and such failure is not remedied within three (3) Business Days after written notice of such failure is given to the Party
perturbation.changed_text: 6.1.1. A Party fails to make, when due, any payment under this JSMA. The Non-Defaulting Party may, at its sole discretion, provide a written notice allowing a cure period of up to 30 business days for the Defaulting Party.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause requires remedy within 3 business days after notice. The modification removes this certainty, granting the Non-Defaulting Party discretion whether to even offer a cure period, and extending it to a maximum of 30 business days, which contradicts the original strict 3-day limit.

perturbation.original_text: 11.1. Neither Party shall assign or transfer any rights or obligations hereunder without the express prior written consent of the other Party, which may not be unreasonably withheld.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.1. Neither Party shall assign or transfer any rights or obligations hereunder. Whether consent will be given shall be at the sole discretion of the other party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text indicates that consent cannot be unreasonably withheld, providing some limitation on the other party's decision. The revised text removes this limitation and grants absolute discretion, creating a contradiction about the conditions of assignment.
